title: ‘It Chapter Two’ Reaps Second-Biggest Horror Opening—Behind First ‘It’
text:
The brooding horror sequel “It Chapter Two” gave the domestic box office a much-needed jolt over the weekend.

While this latest film fell short of its predecessor’s record-breaking opening, “Chapter Two” still amassed a strong $91 million in the U.S. and Canada, according to preliminary studio estimates. AT&T Inc. ’s Warner Bros. released the first installment in its two-film adaptation of Stephen King’s classic novel in 2017. “It” grossed a whopping $123.4 million during its first weekend in theaters, a record for a horror movie.

Picking up decent reviews—but not the raves the first film received—“Chapter Two” helps to reinvigorate a box office that heading into the weekend was about 6% behind 2018’s bumper year.

The new movie picks up 27 years after the first film’s conclusion, when a group of misfit friends—known as the Losers’ Club—make a pact to reunite should the demonic, sewer-dwelling clown Pennywise reappear. The latest installment’s ensemble cast features Jessica Chastain, James McAvoy and Bill Hader.

“Chapter Two” now ranks as both the second-highest-grossing opening for a horror film and second-highest debut (after “It”) for September, traditionally a sluggish month after studios have just finished rolling out their big summer blockbusters.

“Chapter Two” also did well overseas, grossing $94 million, according to Box Office Mojo.

The sequel’s cooler reception from critics may have depressed the box-office tally for “Chapter Two” and could hamper its overall performance. The film’s nearly three-hour running time was judged as excessive by many critics.

“ ‘It’ was really lightning in a bottle…we knew we couldn’t duplicate that,” said Jeff Goldstein, Warner Bros.’s head of domestic distribution.

For Warner Bros., the robust opening is welcome news after a lackluster summer that included only a couple respectable showings—“Pokémon Detective Pikachu” and “Annabelle Comes Home”—and one costly misfire in “Godzilla: King of the Monsters.”

Should “Chapter Two” build on its successful first weekend, Warner Bros. could finish the year strong with highly anticipated films yet to come. The studio will release “Joker,” starring Joaquin Phoenix, next month, followed in November by “Doctor Sleep,” another adaptation of a King novel, this one a follow-up to “The Shining.”

“Chapter Two” was the only major film opening over the weekend. Holdovers “Angel Has Fallen,” from Lions Gate Entertainment Corp. , and the raunchy comedy “Good Boys,” from Comcast Corp. ’s Universal Pictures, placed a distant second and third, respectively.

Write to R.T. Watson at rt.watson@wsj.com
